> ok now let's fix our ~/.claude which contains .coditect (now that we have 
an installer we do not need it there
Bash(ls -la ~/.claude/)

total 1976     drwx------@ 24 halcasteel  staff     768 Nov 19 12:54 .
     drwxr-x---+ 63 halcasteel  staff    2016 Nov 19 12:54 ..
     … +31 lines (ctrl+o to expand)

Current ~/.claude has:
  - .coditect/ directory (full copy)
  - Symlinks pointing to it (agents, commands, skills, etc.)
  - Claude Code internals (debug, history, projects, settings, etc.)

  Plan: Remove .coditect and its symlinks, keep Claude Code internals.

Bash(cd ~/.claude && rm -rf .coditect && rm -f agents commands docs hooks
      orchestration scripts skills templates && ls -la)

total 1976     drwx------@ 15 halcasteel  staff     480 Nov 19 12:59 .
     drwxr-x---+ 63 halcasteel  staff    2016 Nov 19 12:54 ..
     … +14 lines (ctrl+o to expand)

Cleaned up. ~/.claude now contains only Claude Code internals:
  - debug/, file-history/, history.jsonl
  - ide/, projects/, session-env/
  - settings.json, settings.local.json
  - shell-snapshots/, statsig/, todos/

  Removed:
  - .coditect/ directory
  - All symlinks (agents, commands, skills, etc.)

  When you run the installer, it will create fresh symlinks from ~/.claude
  to /opt/coditect.

> now modify so that we can push itermittent updates
I'll add on-demand update checking and configurable update frequency:
Update(update.sh)

[main ab1eff6] Add intermittent updates with silent hourly checks      5 files changed, 104 insertions(+), 25 deletions(-)
      create mode 100755 bin/coditect-check
     … +4 lines (ctrl+o to expand)

Done. Update behavior:

  Hourly background checks:
  - Silent when up-to-date (no output, no notification)
  - macOS notification only when update is installed

  User commands:
  coditect-update     # Update now
  coditect-check      # Check without installing
  coditect-version    # Show current version

  Flags:
  coditect-update --check   # Same as coditect-check
  coditect-update --force   # Force reinstall
  coditect-update --quiet   # Suppress console output

> how are they going to be aware that there is an update?

Good point - currently it auto-installs then notifies. Better approach:
  notify when available, let user install.

Updated update.sh with 9 additions and 1 removal       76        exit 0
       77    fi
       78    
       79 -  # If we get here, there's an update 
          -  - always notify even in quiet mode
       79 +  # If we get here, there's an update available
       80    
       81    # Get commit info
       82    COMMITS_BEHIND=$(git rev-list --count 
            HEAD..origin/$CODITECT_BRANCH)
       83    LATEST_MSG=$(git log -1 --format="%s" 
            origin/$CODITECT_BRANCH)
       84    
       85 +  # In quiet mode (background checks), just notify - don't 
          + auto-install
       86 +  if [ "$QUIET" = true ]; then
       87 +      if command -v osascript &> /dev/null; then
       88 +          osascript -e "display notification 
          + \"${COMMITS_BEHIND} update(s) available. Run: 
          + coditect-update\" with title \"CODITECT Update Available\"" 
          + 2>/dev/null || true
       89 +      fi
       90 +      exit 0
       91 +  fi
       92 +  
       93    if [ "$CHECK_ONLY" = true ]; then
       94        log "${YELLOW}Update available!${NC}"
       95        log "  Current: ${LOCAL_SHORT}"

Bash(git add update.sh && git commit -m "Notify on update available, don't
      auto-install…)

[main 3d5d70a] Notify on update available, don't auto-install      1 file changed, 9 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)
     To https://github.com/halcasteel/coditect.git
        ab1eff6..3d5d70a  main -> main

Now the flow is:

  1. Hourly background check (silent)
  2. If update available → macOS notification: "X update(s) available. Run:
  coditect-update"
  3. User decides when to install → coditect-update

  Users are in control - notified but not auto-updated.

> how do they install?

After getting the notification, they run:

  coditect-update

  This installs the update and shows:
  Installing update...
    abc123 -> def456 (3 commits)
  Updated successfully!
    Version: def456
    Message: Add new feature X

  The notification text tells them exactly what to run: "X update(s)
  available. Run: coditect-update"

> then we need to add new CODITECT commands?

Yes - let's add Claude Code slash commands so users can update from within
   Claude:

     … +14 lines (ctrl+o to expand)

Bash(git add commands/ && git commit -m "Add Claude Code slash commands for
      update management…)

[main f2a7300] Add Claude Code slash commands for update management      3 files changed, 65 insertions(+)
      create mode 100644 commands/coditect-check.md
     … +4 lines (ctrl+o to expand)

Done. Users now have two ways to manage updates:

  Terminal commands:
  coditect-update     # Install updates
  coditect-check      # Check for updates
  coditect-version    # Show version

  Claude Code slash commands:
  /coditect-update    # Install updates
  /coditect-check     # Check for updates
  /coditect-version   # Show version

  Both work - terminal for quick access, slash commands for within Claude
  Code sessions.

> what else am I forgetting?

Good question. Key things that might be missing:

  Critical:
  1. Source repo accessible? - Installer clones
  halcasteel/coditect-project-dot-claude - is that repo public on GitHub?
  2. LICENSE file - No license in the distribution repo

  Important:
  3. Version/CHANGELOG - No version tags or release notes
  4. Rollback - No way to revert a bad update
  5. Health check - Command to verify installation is working
  6. Requirements doc - macOS only currently (launchd), needs git

  Nice to have:
  7. Linux support - launchd is macOS-specific
  8. Troubleshooting guide - Common issues and fixes
  9. Configuration - Update frequency preferences
  10. First-run verification - Test that everything works after install

  Most urgent: Is halcasteel/coditect-project-dot-claude a public GitHub
  repo? The installer will fail if it can't clone it.

  Want me to address any of these?
